We replaced a varying fraction of users by sybil devices and measured number of individually extractable data points from the target user and average SNRs over all their reconstructions. The more benign users participate in the round, the less effective data reconstruction becomes.

We first perform direct extraction from noisy gradients.
The extraction of data points works exactly the same way as for vanilla FL¬†
, by initializing the model with trap weights before sending it to the target user, and then projecting their received gradients back to the input domain.
shows the full resulting extracted data in a setup with a mini-batch of 20 data points,

While some noisy reconstructed data points resemble the original training data, other are less recognizable because they are an overlay of multiple data points, or are dominated by the added noise. DDP setup:

.
We report further results for MNIST and ImageNet in Appendix¬†
We, furthermore, conducted experiments to quantify the effect of not replacing all other

users by sybil devices, but only a fraction of the other users.
Therefore, we conducted experiments with extracting data from one round of the FL protocol with 50 participants, each holding a mini-batch of 20 data points.
Our goal was to study what privacy gain the presence of other benign users incurs on the target user.
We visualize our results in

.
They suggest that when the target user is sampled solely with sybil devices (row 1), the server is able to extract 95% of their individual training data points individually, protected solely by the noise added locally according to DDP.
The more benign users participate in the protocol round, the lower SNRs of the reconstructed data from the target user, and the fewer of the target user‚Äôs individual data points can be individually extracted.
This effect stems from the aggregation within the SA, which overlays gradients from all users before sharing them with the server.
Our results are aligned with findings by
who showed that averaging over several mini-batches (which is precisely the effect of the SA) degrades extraction success.

, under the influence of how much noise, the reconstruction of a data point is sufficiently close to the original data point is orthogonal to this work.
In particular, it will depend on the specific domain, task, and user-preference.
However, users in FL should assume that the server can extract individual data points such as the ones depicted in
In the following, we will show how the server can improve the fidelity of extraction by leveraging the redundancy of extractable data due to the trap weights.
